title: Implement agent credential broker
description: Create a secure mechanism for coding agents to request short-lived, scoped credentials. Options: 1Password Service Accounts, AWS IAM Identity Center CLI, or custom broker service. Must support: ephemeral tokens (300s TTL), scoped permissions, audit logging.

title: Migrate existing CDK to Pulumi
description: Import existing AWS CDK S3/IAM resources into Pulumi. Steps: 1) pulumi import existing resources, 2) Convert CDK stack to Pulumi TypeScript, 3) Verify no drift, 4) Remove CDK directory

title: Set up Pulumi TypeScript infrastructure
description: Initialize Pulumi TypeScript project for multi-cloud infrastructure. Steps: 1) npm install pulumi, 2) pulumi new typescript, 3) Configure AWS and Cloudflare providers, 4) Set up state backend (Pulumi Cloud or S3)

title: Configure GitHub Actions OIDC for AWS
description: Set up OIDC federation between GitHub Actions and AWS IAM. This enables CI/CD to deploy without stored credentials. Steps: 1) Add GitHub OIDC provider to AWS IAM, 2) Create IAM role with trust policy for repo, 3) Add workflow that uses aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials

title: Configure GitHub Actions OIDC for Cloudflare
description: Set up OIDC federation between GitHub Actions and Cloudflare API. This enables deploying Workers and managing R2 without stored API tokens. Steps: 1) Create Cloudflare API token with scoped permissions, 2) Configure OIDC provider in Cloudflare, 3) Add workflow for Cloudflare deployments

title: Set up Cloudflare R2 bucket infrastructure
description: Create R2 buckets for static assets, application data, and backups. Configure CORS, lifecycle rules, and public access settings. Integrate with Cloudflare CDN for edge delivery.

title: Create CI/CD pipeline for main branch deployments
description: GitHub Actions workflow that triggers on merge to main. Deploys: 1) Vercel frontend (auto via git integration), 2) Pulumi infrastructure changes, 3) Cloudflare Workers, 4) Run migrations if needed.
